articles.headline: Trump Disavows ‘Send Her Back’ Chant After Pressure From G.O.P.
articles.snippet: But as the crowd chanted at his re-election rally in North Carolina, President Trump looked around and seemed to bask in the enthusiastic refrain.
articles.abstract: But as the crowd chanted at his re-election rally in North Carolina, President Trump looked around and seemed to bask in the enthusiastic refrain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nervous Republicans, from senior members of Congress to his own daughter Ivanka, urged President Trump on Thursday to repudiate the “send her back” chant directed at a Somali-born congresswoman during his speech the night before at a rally in North Carolina, amid widespread fears that the rally had veered into territory that could hurt their party in 2020.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Maggie Haberman and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: New York Awards Offshore Wind Contracts in Bid to Reduce Emissions
articles.snippet: The wind projects are meant to be an important component of the state’s plan to get 70 percent of its electricity from renewable sources by 2030.
articles.abstract: The wind projects are meant to be an important component of the state’s plan to get 70 percent of its electricity from renewable sources by 2030.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York State, which last month passed an ambitious law to reduce the emissions that cause climate change, said Thursday that it had reached an agreement for two large offshore wind projects.

articles.headline: Boeing Says Charges Tied to 737 Max Grounding to Reach $8 Billion
articles.snippet: The company, which had already announced $1 billion in costs from the jet’s grounding after two crashes, added $5.6 billion to compensate airlines and $1.7 billion due to a production slowdown.
articles.abstract: The company, which had already announced $1 billion in costs from the jet’s grounding after two crashes, added $5.6 billion to compensate airlines and $1.7 billion due to a production slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial fallout from the troubled 737 Max jetliner continues to swell for Boeing, which on Thursday announced $7.3 billion in costs that will hit its bottom line.

articles.headline: Trump to Nominate Eugene Scalia for Labor Secretary Job
articles.snippet: Mr. Scalia, the son of Antonin Scalia who worked in the Bush administration, is expected to bring a pro-business approach and stability to the Labor Department.
articles.abstract: Mr. Scalia, the son of Antonin Scalia who worked in the Bush administration, is expected to bring a pro-business approach and stability to the Labor Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump said Thursday that he would name Eugene Scalia as his next secretary of labor, tapping the longtime labor lawyer and son of the former Supreme Court justice Antonin Scalia for a position with vast responsibility over the American work force.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Noam Scheiber and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: Trump Says He May Intervene in Huge Pentagon Contract Sought by Amazon
articles.snippet: The company, long a target of President Trump, is seen as the leading competitor for a $10 billion cloud computing contract that the president said he was “getting tremendous complaints about.”
articles.abstract: The company, long a target of President Trump, is seen as the leading competitor for a $10 billion cloud computing contract that the president said he was “getting tremendous complaints about.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Thursday that he was looking “very seriously” at intervening in the hard-fought commercial battle for a $10 billion Pentagon cloud computing contract for which Amazon, a company he has frequently attacked, is seen as the leading contender.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Would You Let the Man Who Killed Your Sister Out of Prison?
articles.snippet: Rolling back mass incarceration requires new approaches to those who have committed violence. In Ohio, that has meant some hard conversations.
articles.abstract: Rolling back mass incarceration requires new approaches to those who have committed violence. In Ohio, that has meant some hard conversations.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — On a drizzly morning last summer, Patricia Jackson opened her door to two strangers. They told her they had come on behalf of a man named Angelo Robinson.

articles.headline: Safe Deposit Boxes Aren’t Safe
articles.snippet: When Philip Poniz opened Box 105 at his local Wells Fargo, he discovered it was empty — and that he was totally unprotected by federal law.
articles.abstract: When Philip Poniz opened Box 105 at his local Wells Fargo, he discovered it was empty — and that he was totally unprotected by federal law.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, when Philip Poniz moved to New Jersey from Colorado, he needed a well-protected place to stash his collection of rare watches. He had been gathering unusual pieces since he was a teenager in 1960s Poland, fascinated by their intricate mechanics. His hobby became his profession, and by the time of his relocation, Mr. Poniz was an internationally known expert in the history and restoration of high-end timepieces.

articles.headline: When the Law Says Using Marijuana Is O.K., but the Boss Disagrees
articles.snippet: The relatively rapid acceptance of marijuana use in the United States has lawmakers and employers grappling with ways to adjust hiring rules.
articles.abstract: The relatively rapid acceptance of marijuana use in the United States has lawmakers and employers grappling with ways to adjust hiring rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Smoking pot cost Kimberly Cue her job.

articles.headline: Iran’s Seizure of British Vessel Further Roils Gulf Region
articles.snippet: The seizure came a day after the United States said it had shot down an Iranian drone, reviving fears of a military clash in the Persian Gulf.
articles.abstract: The seizure came a day after the United States said it had shot down an Iranian drone, reviving fears of a military clash in the Persian Gulf.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Iran seized at least one British oil tanker in a vital Persian Gulf waterway on Friday, a sharp escalation of tensions with the West that revived fears of a military clash, even as voices on both sides appeared to be seeking room for negotiations.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Megan Specia
